metadata./Title: Small bowel obstruction due to ascariasis in a child from southern Ethiopia: a case report

sections.Background:
Background Ascariasis, caused by the parasitic nematode Ascaris lumbricoides, is estimated to affect just under 900 
million people globally, the majority of whom are children. Infections are most common in impoverished regions 
with poor water, sanitation, and hygiene, as transmission is reliant upon the ingestion of eggs excreted in feces found 
in contaminated soil.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation An 8-year-old Black African boy from the Sidama region, southern Ethiopia, presented at Adare 
General Hospital with a 3-day history of vomiting, abdominal pain, distension, and inability to pass stool or gas. 
Ultrasound confirmed a small bowel obstruction caused by a bolus of A. lumbricoides, which was successfully 
removed by surgical intervention via laparotomy and enterotomy. Postoperative treatment included the administration of anthelmintics and antibiotics, which led to stable recovery, with normal bowel function observed 1 month 
after surgery. The child’s socioeconomic status, environmental conditions, and lack of knowledge about ascariasis 
transmission likely contributed to this severe infection, leading to the occurrence of the small bowel obstruction. 
Critically, his family lacked sanitation facilities, practiced open defecation, and consumed untreated surface water. The 
family did not participate in recent mass drug administration campaigns and had poor awareness of hygiene practices, highlighting gaps in the current national neglected tropical disease control program and deficiencies in public 
health education.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion Despite Ethiopia’s national deworming program being in existence since 2015, the lack of adequate 
water, sanitation, and hygiene infrastructure and awareness of risk-reducing behaviors, including participation 
in mass drug administration campaigns, has culminated in the continuation of A. lumbricoides transmission in many 
communities in Ethiopia. Enhanced mass drug administration coverage and robust water, sanitation, and hygiene 
interventions are the major goals of efforts in Ethiopia to reduce the national worm burden and prevent occurrence 
of severe complications such as small bowel obstruction caused by significant build-up of worms. As the presented 
case highlights, continuous community health education is essential for long-term control, as it increases mass drug 
administration participation and emphasizes the importance of good hygiene practices within communities. Finescale parasitological mapping and regular epidemiological assessments are necessary to identify high-risk families 
and communities and implement necessary treatment strategies.

Background
Ascariasis is a parasitic infection in humans caused by 
Ascaris lumbricoides, which affects just under 900 million 
people globally [1–4]. The nematode is one of three hel minth species, which together are named the soil-trans mitted helminths (STHs). STH infections are among the 
most prevalent worldwide, affecting approximately 1.5 
billion individuals or approximately 24% of the world’s 
population [5]. These infections primarily impact impov erished and underserved communities lacking adequate 
access to clean water, sanitation, and hygiene, particularly 
in tropical and subtropical regions.
A. lumbricoides transmission occurs through the inges tion of infectious eggs, which are excreted in human 
feces and subsequently contaminate soil in regions with 
inadequate sanitation [5]. Morbidity from ascariasis is 
correlated with the worm burden. Light infections typi cally cause no symptoms, whereas severe infections in 
children may lead to intestinal issues such as diarrhea, 
abdominal pain, malnutrition, weakness, stunted growth, 
poor memory and cognition, and even small bowel 
obstruction requiring surgical intervention [5, 6]. The 
control of Ascaris  infections includes the periodic treat ment of high-risk populations in endemic areas with 
anthelmintic medications delivered by mass drug admin istration (MDA); the provision of water, sanitation, and 
hygiene (WaSH) interventions; and the enhancement of 
health and hygiene education [5].
Ethiopia has a heavy national burden of ascariasis. 
Despite years of intervention efforts, it remains a signifi cant public health issue [7–15]. This study reports the 
case of an 8-year-old Black African boy from the Sidama 
region in southern Ethiopia who developed a small bowel 
obstruction due to an A. lumbricoides infestation. We 
identified various factors that contribute to the transmis sion of this severe infection.
Case presentation
An 8-year-old Black African boy from the Hawasa Zuria 
Woreda, Udo Wetate Kebele, was admitted to Adare 
General Hospital at Hawasa on 11 March 2024. The 
child lived in a distant area with a high prevalence of 
STH. Tulla, a neighboring district located 19 km from 
the child’s residential area, was recently surveyed as part 
of the Geshiyaro project in 2024, reporting an A. lum bricoides prevalence in an age-balanced sample of the 
community of 33.2% [95% confidence interval (CI) 30.4–
36.2%] [16].
The child had been experiencing symptoms for 3 
days before being admitted to the hospital, includ ing vomiting, abdominal pain, abdominal disten sion, and an inability to pass stool or gas. The physical examination showed an acutely ill-looking child with 
pink conjunctiva. The abdominal examination revealed 
visible peristalsis and mild tenderness over the right 
lower quadrant. The rectum was empty on digital rec tal examination. The child’s vital signs upon admission 
included a pulse rate of 122 beats per minute, a tem perature of 37.5  °C, and an oxygen saturation of 97%. 
Abdominal and pelvic ultrasound revealed a small 
bowel obstruction caused by a bolus of Ascaris  worms. 
Laparotomy and enterotomy were performed to remove 
the Ascaris  worms, as depicted in Fig.  1. He received a 
one-time oral dose of albendazole (400 mg) along with 
other antibiotics. He was discharged from the hospi tal on postoperative day 7. The patient’s condition was 
stable and satisfactory, with normal bowel function 1 
month after surgery.
Various risk factors, such as socioeconomic status, 
environmental factors, history of MDA, WaSH inter ventions, and behavioral patterns, can contribute to 
the transmission of Ascaris  infection. We identified 
these factors by visiting the child’s home and inter viewing his older brother. Furthermore, we conducted 
interviews with key informants from the National and 
Local Neglected Tropical Disease (NTD) Prevention, 
Control, and Elimination Team. These interviews pro vided additional insights into the local implementa tion of the MDA and WaSH programs that would be 
accessible to the patient. The CARE checklist was used 
to prepare this case report (Additional File 1 ) [17]. Fig ure 2 presents a diagrammatic representation of the A.

In our case, through an interview with an older brother 
and observation of the child’s residential house, we found 
that neither the child nor his family was aware of how A. 
lumbricoides, and more broadly STH, is transmitted from 
person to person. They also lacked knowledge regarding 
preventive measures against any STH infections. None of 
the family members practiced hand washing before meals 
or after using the toilet. In nearly all instances, family 
members do not wash vegetables or fruits before con sumption and consume raw foods without washing. The child was drinking surface water without treatment in the 
days leading up to his admission to the hospital.
We also inquired about the children’s educational status 
and the family members’ occupations and income. There 
were a total of seven individuals residing in the house hold. The child in grade one had to drop out of school 
owing to recent surgery. The child’s mother had no formal 
education, and the highest level of education achieved in 
the household was completion of grade seven. The child’s 
father died 6 years ago from natural causes. Farming was 
the sole source of income for the household, with aver age annual earnings of USD $1000. It took an average of

sections.Discussion:
Discussion and conclusion
The World Health Organization’s (WHO) strategy to 
control STH infections, including ascariasis, focuses on 
reducing morbidity by periodically treating at-risk pop ulations in endemic areas. These populations include 
preschool-aged and school-aged children, women of 
reproductive age (including pregnant and breastfeeding 
women), and adults in high-risk occupations such as tea 
pickers or miners. Treatment aims to reduce worm bur den and associated health issues [5]. During interviews, 
as part of this case study, we inquired whether the sick 
child and his family members had ever participated in 
MDA programs for deworming. None of the school-aged 
children of the family participated in the most recent 
school-based MDA campaign, which was conducted 6 
months prior to the case study.
In November 2015, Ethiopia initiated a nationwide 
school-based deworming program [18, 19]. Although 
significant progress has been made in extending MDA 
coverage across the country, certain groups within the 
population, particularly in hard-to-reach areas of south ern Ethiopia, still face challenges in accessing preventive 
chemotherapy (PC)[18]. In addition, the smooth imple mentation of the program has been affected by various 
factors, such as coronavirus disease-2019 (COVID-19), 
inadequate regional commitment, delays in delivery of 
MDA drugs to lower levels, sporadic internal conflict, 
the presence of a parasitological remapping survey, lim ited human resource motivation, and the unavailability 
of drugs and budget constraints, leading to the partial 
success of the national deworming program [15]. The 
current approach to school-based deworming presents 
challenges, particularly in reaching high-risk popula tions who are not enrolled in school [18]. This shows 
that it is important to extend the treatment population 
to preschool children, women of reproductive age, and 
adults in high-risk occupations. It is imperative to imple ment a regular biannual deworming program in endemic 
areas to reduce the worm burden and decrease the risk 
of severe complications such as small bowel obstruction 
caused by significant build-up of worms [5].
The WHO recommends that endemic nations evalu ate the effectiveness of their MDA programs by con ducting epidemiological assessments approximately 5–6 years after implementing PC, ensuring treatment 
coverage of at least 75%. The MDA frequency in each 
country (annual or biannual) should then be adjusted 
per the latest endemicity

Remapping high-risk areas at regular intervals is 
important for identifying the population at risk for STH 
infections and will ultimately support the design of an 
appropriate national STH control program. Following 
each round of the MDA, it is also important to evalu ate the program’s performance and effectiveness in 
decreasing the prevalence of STH [20]. Two indices—
program reach and survey coverage—are employed for 
MDA program monitoring. However, in our study area, 
only the program reach, determined from handwritten 
records of drug distributors, was utilized, which is sus ceptible to errors. Hence, it is crucial to conduct cov erage evaluation surveys after each round of MDA to 
mitigate the human errors. In Ethiopia, only selected 
regions/areas perform coverage evaluation surveys fol lowing national school-based MDA programs [21]. This 
may lead to incomplete representation of the MDA fig ures across all localities in the country.
The availability of WaSH interventions is crucial for 
the long-term control and prevention of STH. Health 
and hygiene education reduces transmission and rein fection by encouraging healthy behaviors [5 ]. The STH 
control program in Ethiopia faces a number of chal lenges related to WaSH interventions. In our case, the 
child’s household had access to a very poor pit latrine 
located 2 m away from the household. However, none 
of the children residing in the household use the 
latrine; instead, they defecate in nearby farm areas. 
Open defecation was common, and we observed fresh 
feces in many areas of the vicinity. In addition, there 
was no hand washing facility near the toilet, and family 
members did not practice hand washing before meals 
or after using the toilet. Soap was not used for wash ing hands. Furthermore, there were no educational or 
awareness programs regarding hygiene practices in the 
community.
The primary source of drinking water for the house hold was a public tap located a 10-min walk from their 
residence. Although water may be treated centrally by 
the government, there was no mechanism for families 
to treat water at home, and no public health education 
was provided to encourage the use of boiled water for 
drinking. Occasionally, they may also use surface water 
for drinking. Limited sanitation awareness programs 
were available, despite efforts by health extension work ers (HEWs) to engage school-aged students and religious 
leaders in improving sanitation awareness. However, 
there was no adequate program to increase community 
awareness regarding sanitation.

Hence, enhancing WaSH interventions in endemic 
areas is crucial for preventing Ascaris  infection. This 
involves improving access to and utilization of sanita tion facilities, discouraging open defecation practices, 
ensuring access to safe water, implementing effective 
water treatment methods such as boiling, establishing 
proper waste management systems, conducting health 
education campaigns about Ascaris  transmission and 
prevention at the community level, encouraging behav ioral changes such as proper hand washing with soap 
and safe water practices, integrating hygiene education 
into school curricula for vulnerable populations, train ing community health extension workers to deliver 
hygiene education for communities, and advocating 
for the consumption of clean and properly prepared/
cooked food within communities.
Severe A. lumbricoides infections in children can 
result in increased risk of complications such as small 
bowel obstruction. This occurs when a large mass of 
worms blocks the intestinal lumen [5 , 6]. The absence 
of sufficient WaSH infrastructure and limited aware ness of risk-reducing behaviors, including participa tion in MDA campaigns, may have contributed to 
the high worm burden in the intestine. This situation 
underscores the need for improved MDA coverage and 
strengthened WaSH interventions.
